[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Struct: NodeStartupConfig] [Race condition] Is there a TOCTOU (time-of-check-time-of-use) race condition where an attacker can modify the config file between validation and actual use, flipping security flags from false to true? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Struct: NodeStartupConfig] [Serialization round-trip] If NodeStartupConfig is serialized to disk and then deserialized, could bit flips or encoding issues cause false to become true for security flags, disabling security checks on node restart? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Derive: Serialize] [Format confusion] Can an attacker exploit differences between YAML and JSON serialization formats to inject skip_config_sanitizer=true in one format that gets interpreted differently in another format? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Derive: Clone, Copy] [Shallow copy attack] When NodeStartupConfig is cloned using the Copy trait, could there be scenarios where the cloned config has security flags modified independently of the original, causing inconsistent security states across the codebase? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Derive: Clone, Copy] [Memory corruption] Could memory corruption or use-after-free bugs cause copied NodeStartupConfig instances to have corrupted security flag values (e.g., garbage values interpreted as true)? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Derive: Debug] [Information disclosure] Does the Debug implementation log the values of skip_config_optimizer and skip_config_sanitizer to disk or network, potentially revealing to attackers which nodes have security checks disabled? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Derive: Debug] [Log injection] Can an attacker craft NodeStartupConfig values that, when logged via Debug, inject malicious log entries or escape sequences that could be exploited by log analysis tools? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Derive: PartialEq, Eq] [Timing attack] Could the PartialEq implementation for NodeStartupConfig be vulnerable to timing attacks that reveal whether security flags are enabled based on comparison execution time? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Test: test_node_startup_config_default] [Insufficient test coverage] Does the single test only verify default values are false, without testing deserialization edge cases, malicious input handling, or the security implications of setting flags to true? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Test: test_node_startup_config_default] [Missing security tests] Are there no tests verifying that mainnet validators cannot start with skip_config_sanitizer=true, or that failpoints are properly blocked when sanitization is enabled? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Test: test_node_startup_config_default] [Missing fuzzing] Are the skip_config_optimizer and skip_config_sanitizer fields fuzz-tested with malformed input (null bytes, maximum size strings, special characters) to ensure serde deserialization fails safely? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Field: skip_config_optimizer] [Execution config bypass] Can setting skip_config_optimizer=true prevent critical ExecutionConfig optimizations, causing validators to run with suboptimal gas settings or disabled parallel execution, leading to consensus timing issues? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Field: skip_config_optimizer] [Consensus config bypass] Can skip_config_optimizer=true bypass ConsensusConfig optimizations, causing validators to run with incorrect timeout values or disabled consensus observer features, breaking consensus liveness? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Field: skip_config_optimizer] [Storage config bypass] Can setting skip_config_optimizer=true prevent StorageConfig optimization, causing nodes to run without storage sharding or with incorrect pruning settings, leading to state inconsistencies? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Field: skip_config_optimizer] [StateSync bypass] Can skip_config_optimizer=true disable StateSyncConfig optimizations, causing fullnodes to use inefficient sync strategies that could be exploited for resource exhaustion attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Field: skip_config_sanitizer] [Execution sanitizer bypass] Can setting skip_config_sanitizer=true bypass ExecutionConfig sanitization, allowing validators to run with dangerous execution settings that violate consensus invariants? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Field: skip_config_sanitizer] [Consensus sanitizer bypass] Can skip_config_sanitizer=true bypass ConsensusConfig validation, allowing validators to run with invalid consensus parameters that could cause safety violations or Byzantine behavior? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Field: skip_config_sanitizer] [Mempool sanitizer bypass] Can setting skip_config_sanitizer=true bypass MempoolConfig validation, allowing nodes to run with unbounded mempool sizes or zero transaction fees, enabling mempool DoS attacks? [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/node_startup_config.rs] [Field: skip_config_optimizer] [Validator isolation] Can a Byzantine validator use skip_config_optimizer=true to isolate themselves from the validator network by preventing automatic peer discovery, allowing them to selectively participate in consensus only when beneficial for attacks?
